summary: Military commission proceedings were established in 2001 to try Guantánamo detainees: non-U.S.-citizens suspected in terrorism cases. Federal law states that defense counsel in these proceedings shall have a reasonable opportunity to obtain witnesses and other evidence—which could include detainees' medical records. The prosecution is responsible for getting such records and giving them to the defense. Defense teams have cited difficulty getting them, which the prosecution...
title: Guantánamo Bay: Accessing Detainee Medical Records as Part of Military Commissions' Proceedings
